Hubei Key Laboratory of Plasma Chemistry and Advanced Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering Process of Ministry of Education, Wuhan Institute of Technology No. 206 Guanggu 1st Road Wuhan 430205 China Electrocatalytic reaction can convert carbon dioxide (CO2) into formic acid (HCOOH), which is considered as a promising pathway for sustainable energy conversion and valuable chemicals production. Nevertheless, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) to HCOOH exists high reaction potential, insufficient active site and low product selectivity. In this review, various catalysts, including metal and metal oxides, metal-organic frameworks, covalent organic frameworks and carbon-based materials, are summarized from the structure-activity relationship between electrocatalysts and CO2RR performance. Then, the regulation strategies of morphology control, defect engineering, and interface engineering, to improve the selectivity and stability of CO2RR have been successively analyzed. In addition, the practical application of CO2RR to HCOOH in electrochemical energy technologies (formic acid fuel cells and water splitting) are comprehensively discussed. Finally, the perspectives and outlook of advanced catalysts for electrochemical selectivity reduction CO2 to HCOOH are thoroughly addressed. This review will be helpful to provide new insights for designing high selective and stable CO2RR to HCOOH electrocatalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide reduction reaction Formic acid Electrocatalyst Selectivity and stability Energy technologies Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Recently, excessive consumption of fossil fuels has led to excessive emissions of CO2, causing serious environmental problems[1,2]. For example, global warming and greenhouse effect can induce ocean acidification, leading to an increase in extreme weather events[3–5]. These have adverse effects on human health and ecosystems. Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction can convert CO2 into useful chemicals and fuels. This reduces greenhouse gas emissions and recycles carbon resources. Therefore, there is an urgent need to explore various methods to convert CO2 into high-value fuels and chemicals[6]. Electrocatalytic reaction can convert CO2 into carbon monoxide (CO), formic acid (HCOOH), methanol (CH3OH), ethanol (C2H5OH), ethylene(C2H4), and methane(CH4), which is considered as a promising pathway for sustainable energy conversion and chemical products production[7–15]. Particularly, HCOOH as double-electron transfer product of carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) is an ideal hydrogen carrier, more importantly, HCOOH can be used as raw materials for direct formic acid fuel cells and other chemical products[16–18]. Nevertheless, CO2RR to HCOOH exists high reaction potential, insufficient active site and low product selectivity, which needs advanced electrocatalyst to pave the slow kinetics process[19]. In general, an oxygen-bound intermediate of *OCHO to *HCOOH is the rate-determining step to produce formic acid, therefore, a much higher energy barrier for the formation of *OCHO intermediates can inhibit the HCOOH production[20]. In this regard, the selectivity and activity of HCOOH essentially depend on the relative bonding strength of the reaction intermediate on the catalyst active site[21]. In addition, catalyst with appropriate d-band centers and Fermi levels present moderate binds to the intermediates of *OCHO, which can effectively promote proto-electron transfer[22,23]. For instance, P-block metals (Such as Sn, In, Bi, Pb) have a unique electronic structure from ns2np1 to ns2np6, which possess variable valence states and high oxygen affinity, tending to activate CO2 by η(O) adsorption[19,24,25]. Thus, P-block metals and metal oxides has a higher adsorption capacity of OCHO* on the catalyst active site, which can stabilize the intermediate and selectively generate HCOOH. Typically, the organic ligand of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is connected to P-block metals, thus, MOFs has the merits of high porosity and large specific surface area, which is conducive to adsorption and mass transfer during the process of CO2RR to HCOOH[26]. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) as another superior CO2RR electrocatalyst, present stable π-π conjugated structures, which can form many kinds of topological network structure, promoting charge transfer and improving the CO2RR performance[27,28]. Significantly, carbon can act as protection layer to prevent mental oxide from being reduced to a metallic state during the CO2RR process[29–31]. Thus, carbon-based materials with high stability can improve the CO2 adsorption and diffusion kinetics. Recently, several strategies, such as crystal phase regulation[32,33], component modulation[34,35], defects regulation[36,37], and interface engineering[38–40], are widely applied to redistribute the electron structure, which have significant effect on the adsorption strength of the key intermediates, improving the activity and stability of CO2RR to HCOOH. In this review, the recent progress of electrochemical CO2RR to HCOOH are comprehensively summarized. The mechanism of CO2RR to HCOOH, including the energy barrier of intermediate formation, the adsorption of intermediate, and d-band centers, is thoroughly analyzed to illustrate the structure–activity–performance of CO2RR to HCOOH. Successively, the strategies of morphology control, defect engineering, and interface engineering are discussed to optimize the metal and metal oxides, MOFs, COFs and carbon-based catalysts. Then, the application of CO2RR technology as a semi-reaction for formic acid fuel cells and water splitting are discussed. Finally, the perspectives and outlook of advanced catalysts for electrochemical selectivity reduction CO2 to HCOOH in energy technologies are addressed. We hope this review will provide value insights for designing high selective and stable CO2RR to HCOOH electrocatalysts, which is helpful to convert waste carbon dioxide into valuable chemicals and fuels. 2 Reaction mechanism CO2RR as a complicated process involves the transfer of multiple electrons. This results in the formation of different products. These competitive reaction pathways lead to different product distributions[41,42]. Under certain conditions, hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) competes with each proto-coupled electron transfer step of CO2RR. This has a negative effect on the selectivity of CO2RR[36]. The most important step in CO2RR is the first electron transfer to surface-adsorbed *CO2, forming *CO2 · −. The next protonation step depends on the binding of *CO2 · − to the electrode surface[20]. The selectivity and activity of CO2RR are largely dependent on the relative binding strengths of the reactive intermediates (e.g., *OCHO, *COOH, *CO, and *H), the relative binding strength on the catalyst surface. A strong binding to ∗CO prevents ∗CO from being released or reduced, which makes H2 as the main product. On the other hand, a weaker bond with ∗CO allows for the release of ∗CO and the formation of CO. A moderately strong bond with ∗CO allows for reduction and reaction of ∗CO, which results in the formation of C2+ reduction products[21,22,43,44]. However, CO2RR to HCOOH is a double-proton and double-electron transfer progress, which can be represented by the following Eqs. (1–3). When CO2 molecules enter the electrolyte, it can form *CO2 on the catalyst surface, and activate to form CO2 · − radical anion. *CO2 undergoes a series of proton-electron transfer to form *CO2 −, and then oxygen atoms adsorb on the catalyst active site to produce *OCHO or HCOO* ( Fig. 1a-b)[43,44]. In general, the product of CO2RR to formic acid is pH-dependent: at pH < 3.7, the product exists as HCOOH, while at pH > 3.7, it exists as HCOO⁻ (Fig. 1c)[45]. Therefore, increasing the solution pH promotes the deprotonation of the product, reducing the thermodynamic standard equilibrium potential for formate formation[45]. It can also reduce the HER competition. Consequently, CO2RR to formate is more favorable in alkaline solutions. In addition, the adsorption configuration of CO2 has important effect on the formation energy barrier and the selection of intermediate. Generally, an oxygen-bound intermediate of *OCHO to *HCOOH is the rate-determining step to produce HCOOH (Fig. 1d)[20]. Therefore, a much higher energy barrier for the formed *OCHO intermediate can inhibit the HCOOH production. (1) CO2 + e− → *CO2 · − (2-1) *CO2 · − + H+ → *OCHO or (2-2) *CO2 · − + H+ → HCOO* (3) *OCHO + H+ +e−→ HCOOH According to the Sabatier principle, the selectivity and activity of formic acid essentially depend on the relative bonding strength of the reaction intermediate on the catalyst active site[21]. There is a clear volcanic trend between the *OCHO adsorption energy and current densities of CO2RR to HCOOH on different metals (Fig. 1e)[23]. Thus, changing the valence state can redistribute the electron structure, which have significant effect on the adsorption strength of the key intermediates[30]. For instance, metals with weak *OCHO binding energy (e.g., Au, Ag, Pt, Cu) have a weak affinity for oxygen and hydrogen atoms, in addition, these metals present high d-band centers, which can induce unstable adsorption of *OCHO and other side reactions, resulting in low HCOOH selectivity. On the contrary, catalysts with lower d-band centers (such as Zn and Ni) usually have strong adsorption energy with *OCHO intermediates, however, strong adsorption energy will inhibit the desorption of *OCHO on the catalyst. Thus, catalyst with appropriate d-band centers and Fermi levels present moderate binds to the intermediate of *OCHO, which can effectively promote proton-electron transfer[22,23]. When the d-band center of a metal atom moves away from the Fermi level, the average valence state of the metal increases. Moreover, the lower atomic coordination number on the catalyst surface, the higher overlap between the d-band center of the catalyst and the molecular orbital (e.g., 2π*) of the intermediate, will induce stronger intermediate adsorption on the catalyst[46]. For example, the lower atomic coordination number and stronger interaction with *OCHO can increase the adsorption strength of *OCHO on the catalyst surface. This strong adsorption can inhibit the *OCHO form HCOOH, thus affecting the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. 3 CO2RR electrocatalysts Generally, the low CO2 solubility limits the kinetics of CO2RR in the electrolyte[47,48]. In addition, the activation of stable CO2 molecule requires high overpotential[49]. Electrocatalytic CO2RR can drive this process by charge transfer between the electrode and the electrolyte[50]. Electrocatalyst as a key factor can affect the local migration, adsorption, activation, hydrogenation and product desorption, which is beneficial for improving the CO2RR performance[51]. Typically, metals and metal oxides, MOFs, COFs and carbon-based materials are widely developed to improve the performance of CO2RR to HCOOH. However, the process of identifying high-performance catalysts should attempt numerous metal elements, doping concentrations, and positions, which are costly and time-consuming. In recent years, the utilization of artificial intelligence methodologies, such as density flood theory and machine learning, have emerged as promising approaches to address this challenge. These methods facilitate the analysis of voluminous data sets, expediting the catalyst screening and design process[52–54]. Various strategies, including morphology control, defect engineering, and interface engineering, have been introduced to modulate the electronic structures of catalyst, improving the selectivity and stability of CO2RR[55]. 3.1 Metals and metal oxides P-block metals (e.g., Sn, In, Bi, Pb) are a class of post-transition metals (ns2np1 to ns2np6) in which the outermost p-subshell is occupied by the final valence electron, resulting in unique properties such as high electronegativity and low ionization energy. Consequently, P-block metals exhibit a broad spectrum of variable oxidation states, the induced high degree of versatility is beneficial for the formation of P-block compounds with diverse valences ( Fig. 2a). These metals exhibit superior performance to high selectively produce HCOOH by CO2RR (Fig. 2b)[56,57]. More importantly, P-block metals possess variable valence states and high oxygen affinity, tending to activate CO2 by η(O) adsorption[19,25]. Therefore, it has a higher adsorption capacity of OCHO* than COOH* on the catalyst active site, which can stabilize the intermediate and selectively generate HCOOH. Thus, *OCHO plays a pivotal role as an intermediate in the reduction of CO2RR to HCOOH. In general, pure metal exposed to air is easily oxidized to metal oxide, the oxide layer on the metal surface can form a chemical bond with the CO2 molecule, which present more favorable catalytic activity and selectivity compared with the corresponded metal catalysts[19]. Nevertheless, metal oxides have the low electrical conductivity and limited surface catalytic active sites[58]. Sn has a high electronegativity and low ionization energy, which is beneficial for forming strong chemical bonds with oxygen atoms. As articulated by Sabatier's principle, the adsorption energy of the catalyst on the intermediate must be moderate to ensure successful desorption and generation of the desired product. Insufficient or excessive adsorption capacity has negative impact on the selectivity of the reaction[23,59]. Therefore, Sn located near the top of the volcano map has a near-optimal *OCHO adsorption energy[23]. Thus, the introduced metal heteroatoms (such as Cu, Bi, Ag or Pd) into Sn can induce electron transfer and form high-valence Sn (p- and d-band shift up of Sn), which is conducive to the adsorption and stability of *OCHO or HCOO* intermediates in CO2RR. For instance, a bimetallic Ag-SnOx core-shell catalyst was construct by seed growth and galvanic displacement method[60]. The formed SnOx core-shell makes the surface difference between Sn and Ag, resulting in the spontaneous accumulation of Sn on the surface. Therefore, the surface energy of the nanoparticles is minimized. Doping Ag optimizes the conductivity of the catalyst and improves the Faraday efficiency (FE) of formic acid to 80 %[60]. Different from Ag, Bi atom can stabilize the oxidation state of Sn and prevent the reduction of SnO to Sn0 in the CO2RR process. Bi doped SnO can make Bi 6 s form a hybrid region with O 2 s and 2p orbitals, resulting in the increased valence state of Sn (Fig. 2c)[34]. Additionally, doping Bi into Sn-based catalysts can cause the outermost valence p and d orbital of Sn move away from the Fermi level, which is beneficial for the electron transform from the O to the p and d orbitals of the Sn (Fig. 2d)[57,61]. For instance, the prepared Sn-Bi bimetallic nanofolds remain above 90 % FE and the local current density is up to 140 mA cm−2 for 160 h [61]. A machine learning-assisted density functional theory approach was employed to calculate the volume slices of the charge density and the corresponding optimized configurations of the HCOO adsorbate model. At the interface of Sn-Bi, the adsorption of Sn-O is stronger than that of Sn-C, thus producing HCOOH with high selectivity (Fig. 2e)[55,61]. Compared with metal heteroatoms, non-metallic heteroatoms (such as H, S, N and halogens) are much more electronegative, which can be adopted to regulate the electronic structure of metal catalysts[62–64]. Doping S can make Sn charge shift positively, which can induce the active site incline to bind with electron-rich oxygen-containing groups. For example, tin sulfide (π-SnS) nanocrystals were synthesized by a hydrothermal method, a strong bonding strength existed between Sn-S can make S stable in Sn ( Fig. 3a)[65]. Under acidic conditions, the increased peak area of higher content of S-doping in Sn can improve the *OCHO coverage, which enhances the FE of HCOOH to 92.15 % at the industrial current density of −1 A cm−2 (Fig. 3b). Compared with N and S, halogens have higher electronegativity. Doping halogens can cause the d-band center of Sn shift upward, which can induce the accumulation of electrons near halogens and the more positive valence state of Sn, thus promoting the selectivity of CO2RR to HCOOH[62,66,67]. For example, the synthesized Sn3O(OH)2Cl2 catalyst possesses high concentration of Cl located at the stacked nanoplates, and the FE of HCOOH can reach 96.1 % at −0.9 V vs RHE (Fig. 3c-d)[62]. The Sn3O(OH)2Cl2 catalyst contains Sn-Cl and Sn-O bonds. Sn-O moves toward lower energy and Sn is in a lower valence state, this obvious electron transfer from Sn to Cl reduces the binding energy of *OCHO, improving the selectivity of CO2RR to HCOOH (Fig. 3e). 3.2 Metal-organic frameworks MOFs has the merits of high porosity and large specific surface area, which is conducive to adsorption and mass transfer[26,68]. A new approach uses a combination of MOFs and single-atom catalysts (SACs)[69]. More importantly, the porous structure of MOFs exposes more active sites and enriches reaction intermediates[25]. In general, the active site of CO2RR to HCOOH is located at the center of MOFs, and the organic ligand is connected to P-block metals. However, its high surface energy is easy to aggregate during the synthesis and CO2RR process, which reduces the CO2RR performance[25,70–72]. Low-Dimensional MOFs (LD MOFs) have more functionalized open sites, ultrathin structures, and tunable compositions. They are considered as the ideal precursors for the preparation of SACs. LD MOFs include one-dimensional (1D) structures, such as nanorods, nanotubes, and nanowires, and two-dimensional (2D) structures, such as nanosheets, nanoplates, and nanosheets[69,73]. Bi-MOFs have clear coordination environment, exposed active sites and controllable structure, it is beneficial for increasing the contact area between the reactant molecules and catalyst, reducing the aggregation or deactivation of the active site[25]. For example, Bi nanoparticles with different particle sizes (400 ℃, Bi particle size < 10 nm) were obtained by ultrasonic assisted calcination method[74]. Bi-MOFs are easy to be functionalized and to introduce structural defects in the synthesis process, which can increase the exposure of active sites [75]. MOFs combined with the single atomic electrocatalyst is another effective strategy to optimize the CO2RR performance. Through rapid thermal shock treatment, the structure of Bi-MOF can be significantly altered to form a 2D nanosheet structure (Bi-MOF-TS). These nanosheet structures resemble the morphology of two-dimensional materials, with a larger specific surface area and more exposure to active sites[76]. However, 2D MOFs are relatively unstable, especially in electrochemical reactions, where the reactivity of the ligand may lead to structural instability[77–79]. Three-dimensional (3D) MOFs usually have higher structural stability and can maintain their structural integrity under a wider range of conditions. Bi(III) ions tend to form stable complexes with ligands by multiple O and N coordination sites, which is beneficial for Bi(III) building metal-organic frame structures with these ligands[75,80]. For example, bismuth-based Zeolitic metal–organic framework (Bi-ZMOF, denote PZH-1) with topological crystal structure was prepared by ligand-oriented strategy. A strong coordination bond formed between Bi with pyrazole-N atom can facilitate the charge transfer from N atoms to Bi atoms ( Fig. 4a)[81]. The lone pair electrons of the ligand will be transferred to the metal center, which can reduce the overpotential of the formed intermediate and stabilize the intermediate, obtaining 91 % FE of the produced formic acid (Fig. 4b-c). In addition, a metal node can be connected to an organic ligand by metal coordination bond, forming a 3D porous MOFs structure. For instance, a nitrile-modified UiO-66 MOF film (UiO-66-CN) was prepared on bismuth foil (Fig. 4d-e), and the FE of HCOOH can up to 93 % (at −0.75 V vs RHE)[82]. Nitrile, located at the missing connection point of UiO-66, can form a stable interaction with CO2 molecules at the Bi and UiO-66-CN interfaces, which is helpful to capture and activate CO2 molecules in the pores, stabilizing *OCHO intermediates through secondary spheroidal interactions. A conductive-based framework with Bi-enriched sites can solve the disadvantages of low conductivity and saturated coordination of Bi-MOFs. In this regard, a conductive catecholate-based framework (2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene, HHTP) with Bi-enriched sites (noted Bi-HHTP) was constructed by solvothermal method (Fig. 4f)[83]. The FE of HCOOH exceeds 95 % (−0.7 V vs. RHE), and its catalytic energy efficiency is 68.8 % (Fig. 4i). This can be ascribed to the coordination of Bi3+ with catechol groups formed an unsaturated coordination environment. The ligand-to-metal charge transfer between π-π* and Bi3+ ions and HHTP indicates that Bi-HHTP has strong selectivity for HCOOH formation (Fig. 4g-h)[84,85]. Therefore, the rich unsaturated coordination and high porosity of organometallic framework can be contributed to high FE of CO2RR. 3.3 Covalent organic frameworks COFs with stable π-π conjugated structures can form many kinds topological network structure ( Fig. 5a)[86], which can promote charge transfer and greatly improve the CO2RR performance[27,28] Nevertheless, compared with conventional metal-based electrocatalysts, the primitive COFs present limited exposed active site and low conductivity. In this regard, a template (such as polystyrene spheres) assisted strategy was used to introduce macropores and the inherent microporosity of COFs[87]. In addition, ions (e.g., Cu2+, Zn2+, Fe atom) have been utilized to adjust the electronic properties of COFs and regulate the Fermi level[88–91]. The presence of dopant ions (e.g., Cu2+, Zn2+, Fe3+) within the conjugated system of COFs can result in a charge transfer phenomenon[92]. The doping of ions, such as Cu2+ or Zn2+, has been observed to cause an upward shift in the Fermi level of COFs. This shift is attributed to the increased electron density within the COFs, leading to a higher energy position of the Fermi levels. This upshifted Fermi level has been shown to enhance the adsorption of CO₂ by the COFs, thereby boosting their catalytic activity. For instance, the introduction of typical ions (e.g., Fe3+) can result in a downward shift of the Fermi level of COFs. This downshifted Fermi level can be contributed to the stabilization of intermediates in the CO2 reduction process, leading to an improvement in catalytic selectivity[93,94]. In general, the synergistic effect of structural characteristics and synergistic coordination will reduce the band gap, which is conducive to the absorption and activation of CO2, improving the catalytic activity and selectivity of CO2RR[95]. For example, Fe atom were introduced into the COFs space group symmetry, which can maintain the basic structure of COFs. Fe contributes significantly to the larger d-subshell electron density and total density around Fermi level, increasing the conductivity of COFs and improving the tunability of electronic properties[96]. Nevertheless, COFs in water can degrade to change its crystallinity and permeability, the resulted frame decomposition will affect the stability and durability of the catalyst[97]. Several elements, such as O, N, H, C, B, are connected by strong covalent bonds to form a porous structure[98]. By introducing N atoms into COFs, a perfectly covalently bonded carbon framework can be formed[99]. For instance, nitrogenated COFs (N-COFs) has a high specific surface area of more than 2700 m2 g−1, layered crystal structure with high crystallinity present excellent stability at high temperature (800 ℃)[100]. The lone pair electrons on the N atoms can form hydrogen bonds with the carbonyl O atoms in the CO2 molecule, which increases the electron density on N atoms, promoting the electrons transfer from N atoms to the π* orbitals of CO2 molecules [101]. The superior C-N bond and the high conductivity of the ionized skeleton can induce a higher CO2 desorption signal, enhancing the adsorption capacity of CO2 on the C-N bond (Fig. 5b)[102]. The incorporation of electron-rich atoms can effectively increase the delocalization degree and electron density of the p orbitals of metals, leading to the transfer of pores to Fermi level and promoting the CO2 activation step[103,104]. Co as a typical electron rich atom can change the electronic structure of different electrocatalysts. In this regard, doping Co and the introduction of N ions through post-synthetic modifications can significantly alter the electronic structure of COFs (Fig. 5c)[102]. For instance, Co-N-COF anchored Co atoms was constructed by using N-COF as a carrier (Fig. 5d)[100]. The concentration of Co2 + in Co-N-COF significantly reduces the electron band gap of Co-N-COF, thereby transferring electrons from the top of the valence band to the bottom of the conduction band (Fig. 5e). The maximum FE of HCOOH can achieve 97.4 % over a wide voltage range (at −0.75 V ∼ −1.05 V vs RHE), HCOOH partial current densities can achieve 446 mA cm−2 and stabile for 100 h. Thus, COF material is regarded as a promising catalyst for CO2RR to HCOOH. 3.4 Carbon-based materials Carbon-based catalysts, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers, mesoporous carbon, present large pore structure and well-dispersed surface functional groups, which can improve the CO2 adsorption and diffusion kinetics[105–108]. More importantly, carbon with high stability can act as protection layer to prevent mental oxide from being reduced to a metallic state during the electrolysis process[29–31]. Generally, the greater negative shift of adsorption potential in the alkaline electrolyte will induce the stronger affinity for OH−, which can stabilize the *CO2·− intermediate. In this regard, a carbon-coated indium oxide catalyst (In2O3@C) was constructed by hydrothermal method and high temperature calcination ( Fig. 6a)[109]. There exist the negative shift of lattice oxygen peak in In2O3@C and positive shift in In 3d5/2. The results indicate that electrons may be transferred from In2O3 to the carbon layer, thus dispersing the electron density of In2O3 (Fig. 6b-c). In addition, the presence of oxygen vacancies can help to stabilize the oxidation state of metal sites, preventing excessive reduction or corrosion of metal sites during the CO2RR process[30]. The designed In2O3@C with rich oxygen vacancies presents high specific surface area and preserves 90 % selectivity of HCOO− at a wide voltage range (at −0.8 V ∼ −1.3 V vs RHE) (Fig. 6d-e)[109]. The introduced oxygen vacancies can enhance the adsorption of carbon dioxide, change the d-band center and electronic structure of In2O3, improving its binding ability with *CO2 · −. However, the resulted HCOO− needs to be further separated and purified into HCOOH. Doping N atoms can increase the micropores and surface area of carbon materials, which can increase the active sites and improve the utilization rate[110,111]. In this regard, an electron-rich catalytic environment around the site can be adopted to reduce the reaction energy barrier and promote the formation of HCOOH. For example, a In NPs/chitosan derived N-doped defective graphene (In/N-dG) catalyst was prepared from chitosan[112]. The decreased d-band center of the In/N-dG increases the electron density on the N-dG substrate (Fig. 6f-g). The FE of HCOOH maintains at 96.0 % over a wide potential window across −0.74 V to −1.17 V vs RHE (Fig. 6h). In addition, heteroatom-doped carbon-supported metal catalysts can regulate the inherent electronic structure of carbon substrate, adjust the Fermi level of electrocatalyst as well as change Lewis acidity and alkalinity[113,114]. Individual metal atoms are fixed to carbon-based carriers by forming coordination bonds with N atoms, such as mental-Nx. This coordination environment is conducive to regulating the electronic structure of metal atoms and ensuring adequate exposure of the active site. For instance, an atomically dispersed In-N-C catalyst was synthesized (Fig. 6i)[115]. Its atomically dispersed In site and strong electron interaction with the surrounding N atom can induce the d-band center shift upward relative to the In. The formed In-N coordination enhances the adsorption of intermediate *OCHO and achieves efficient conversion of CO2 to HCOOH. However, the unsaturated coordination and high surface energy of metal atoms are easy to migrate and aggregate, which can lead to the formation of metal clusters or nanoparticles, reducing the activity and selectivity of the catalyst[111,116]. The high specific surface area and abundant defect sites on the carrier are conducive to increasing the load of metal atoms and preventing their aggregation, thereby improving the activity and durability of the catalyst. 4 Electrochemical energy technologies 4.1 Formic acid fuel cells HCOOH as a high energy density hydrogen storage product can be continuously produced by electrochemical CO2RR under P-block metal catalysts. More importantly, HCOOH can be directly fed into the fuel cell to form a direct formic acid fuel cells. In general, a direct formic acid fuel cells uses HCOOH as aqueous solution and O2 in the air instead of a fuel to generate electricity[117–119]. Nevertheless, the difficult activation/cleavage of C═O bonds limits CO2RR kinetics. In addition, the HCOOH product needs to be further separated and purified accompanied with concentrated from electrolyte solution for subsequent application or storage[120,121]. In general, several factors, such as electrolyte, membrane electrode assembly and HCOOH concentration, can affect the performance of formic acid fuel cells[122–127]. The concentration of HCOOH can directly affect the current density and the transmembrane flux of HCOOH. Increasing the HCOOH concentration will spread from the high concentration area to the low concentration area, nevertheless, high HCOOH concentration will damage membrane electrode assembly (MEA), degrading the performance of formic acid fuel cells[128,129]. In addition, catalyst as the key factors can affect the performance of formic acid fuel cells. Precious metal catalysts (such as Pd and Pt) with superior activity have been widely applied in the formic acid fuel cells. For instance, the activity of Pt/Pd mixed metal nanoparticles prepared by spontaneous deposition present 1 mA cm−2 current density of HCOOH oxidation at 0.27 V, which is twice higher than that of pure Pt with HCOOH[130]. Due to the dependence between the size effect of nanoparticles and catalytic activity, larger nanoparticles are easy to cause agglomeration, and 5–7 nm Pd nanoparticles are most conducive to the electrooxidation of HCOOH[131,132]. Hetero-structured platinum-palladium alloy and oxides nanowires (PtPd-ox NWs) were synthesized by a self-sacrificing template method, a polymer fiber membrane was used to separate the cathode and anode in a single cell, and a commercially available Pt/C electrocatalyst was adopted as the cathode electrocatalyst ( Fig. 7a). A single cell with a PtPd-ox NWs anode has an open circuit voltage of 0.92 V and a peak power density of 43.3 mW cm−2, which are higher than that of the Pt/C electrocatalyst[124]. Electrocatalysts with different morphologies, such as dendritic[133] and nano-flower[134], can be used to improve the porosity and surface area. For instance, the catalyst with core-shell structure can improve the porosity and surface area. The PtPbBi/PtBi core-shell nanoparticles have an uneven surface and jagged edges, and the PtPbBi/PtBi nanoparticles can achieve a power density of 161.5 mW cm−2 in the MEA test[125]. Nevertheless, the high cost, poor selectivity and stability of precious metal catalysts for HCOOH have been the main obstacles to their large-scale application. P-block metals have been shown to be the promising catalysts for CO2RR to HCOOH. Recently, various strategies, such as metal alloying, nanostructure, heteroatom doping and regulation in electronic structure and morphology, can be used to optimize the CO2RR activity and stability of P-block metal catalysts (Fig. 7b)[120,124,135]. Particularly, impurities or defects in nanostructured electrocatalysts with large surface area can improve catalytic stability[136,137]. Bi2O3 treated with n-butyllithium with rich grain boundaries can facilitate the contact between catalyst and membrane in the MEA. In an all-solid-state electrochemical CO2RR system, a porous solid electrolyte layer was adopted for rapid ion transport for the continuous production of high-purity and high-concentration HCOOH (Fig. 7c-d)[123]. At neutral pH conditions, the partial current density of HCOOH can up to 450 mA cm⁻², and maintain high activity and selectivity for 100 h[138]. Bi-based catalysts with abundant lattice distortion defects can produce high concentrations of HCOOH in a solid electrolyte reactor, which can be directly used to drive direct formic acid fuel cells with a power density of 55 mW cm⁻2 for 300 h (Fig. 7e-f)[123]. 4.2 Water splitting CO2RR as a semi-reaction of water splitting can convert waste CO2 into useful chemicals and clean energy, realizing the resource reuse[139,140]. Electrolyte plays a key role in carbon dioxide reduction, both as a medium for electron transport and as a participant in the formation of intermediates. In general, the electrolyte in CO2RR can balance protons through anode reaction. The performance of the electrocatalyst can be regulated by controlling the concentration, cation and anion ratio, and pH of electrolyte[46,137]. However, CO2 reduction and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) occur simultaneously during the water splitting process. In general, catalysts can significantly affect the selectivity of HCOOH and the overall efficiency of water splitting[141,142]. For instance, heteroatom-doped P-block metals as an effective strategy can be used to regulate the electronic structure, providing active sites with strong CO2 adsorption and inhibiting the HER. For example, P doped In2O3 catalyst with nanosheet structure presents high valence state[141]. Oxide-derived In and phosphorus-modified oxide-derived In were formed during in-situ reduction, which greatly improved the performance of CO2RR to formate ( Fig. 8a)[141]. Under alkaline conditions, water molecules exist in the form of hydrated base cation clusters, thus exhibiting excellent CO2 reduction properties to HCOOH. In addition, CO2RR is usually coupled with oxygen evolution reaction (OER). However, slow OER kinetics results in high overpotential and energy consumption. Based on thermodynamics, several powerful anodic substitution reactions, including oxidation of alcohols, biomass, chlorine and water contaminants, are proposed to improve the efficiency of water splitting and produce more value-added chemicals (Fig. 8b)[143,144]. Typically, anodic 5-hydroxymethylfurfural electrochemical oxidation (HMFOR) can be introduced to replace the slow OER. For example, indium oxyhydroxide with rich oxygen-vacancy (InOOH-OV) can act as a bifunctional catalyst, this constructed InOOH-OV catalyst presents superior catalytic performance for CO2RR to HCOOH and the HMFOR to 2, 5-furan dicarboxylic acid (Fig. 8c)[143]. In addition, bismuth doped single copper atom (Cu1Bi) was used as the cathode for CO2RR, and NiCo layered double hydroxide (NiCo LDHs) was adopted as the anode for OER. Cu1Bi can promote the dissociation of water and enhances the proton supply capacity. The presence of NiCo LDHs catalyst can reduce the activation energy of HMFOR reaction and accelerate the charge transfer at the electrode-electrolyte interface[145]. As a result, the CO2RR-HMFOR system presents a battery voltage of 2.7 V at the current density of 237 mA cm⁻², which is 0.8 V lower than the conventional CO2RR-OER system (Fig. 8d-e). 5 Perspectives and outlook In this review, recent achievements of advanced electrocatalysts for electrochemical selectivity reduction CO2 to HCOOH are summarized. Originating from the structure-activity relationship between electrocatalysts and CO2RR performance, various strategies, including morphology, alloying, doping and defect engineering, can be effectively applied to construct superior electrocatalysts. In addition, the effects of catalytic environment (such as pH and microenvironment) on catalyst surface should be considered on the practical application of CO2RR to HCOOH in electrochemical energy technologies (formic acid fuel cells and water splitting). Despite the obtained achievements of CO2RR in electrocatalysis, some problems still exist in the construction of high selective and stable CO2RR to HCOOH electrocatalysts. Firstly, the large-scale application of CO2RR technology in industrial production faces various challenges, such as cost-effectiveness, system stability and feasibility of long-term operation. Developing high-activity, high-selectivity and high-stability electrocatalysts is important for improving the performance of CO2RR. In general, balancing the relationship between activity, selectivity and stability should be considered. For instance, nanostructure and defect engineering is an effectivity strategy for constructing stable and highly effective catalysts. In addition, it is vital to design synthesis or modification methods with high efficiency, low cost, and easy extension. For example, constructing hetero-interfaces is an effective and easy strategy to improve the CO2RR performance. Moreover, electrocatalysts with the complex structure is difficult to determine the real active site. In order to reveal the behavior of carbon dioxide molecules, reaction intermediates and catalysts during electrocatalysis, the relationship between CO2RR and electrocatalyst performance can be effectively analyzed by theoretical calculation combined with in-situ characterization techniques. For instance, in-situ raman, in-situ attenuated total reflectance infrared spectroscopy, X-ray absorption spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy can be adopted to capture the precise transformation of catalyst composition, structure, and adsorption intermediates, illustrating the real active sites of CO2RR. In addition, artificial intelligence methods, such as density functional theory and machine learning, which is the general trend to assisted design catalyst. Secondly, developing highly effective carbon dioxide electrolyzer system is vital in the practical applications. CO2RR electrolyzers include H-cells, microfluidicflow electrolyzers, MEA electrolyzer, and solid oxide electrolyzers. For instance, H-cells and microfluidicflow electrolyzers can separate cathode and anode products, nevertheless, the anode and anode are far apart, and the existence of ion exchange membrane may cause high ohmic resistance, resulting in high battery voltage and low energy efficiency of H-cells. MEA with polymer electrolyte membrane presents high ionic conductivity. However, the internal environment of the MEA electrolyzer is difficult to adjust, and some liquid products (such as formic acid, ethanol) are difficult to carry out through the gas flow. Solid oxide electrolyzer has an ion-conductive solid oxide, which can act as electrolyte to separate the anode and cathode. More importantly, solid oxide electrolyzer has higher electrolytic current density, energy efficiency and stability, which presents promising practical application towards CO2RR to HCOOH. Finally, the electrolyte for CO2RR to HCOOH is usually KHCO3 or KOH, the separation and purification of HCOOH is difficult, thus, its effective recovery rate and new separation processes need to be developed. Currently, the separation and purification methods for HCOOH include reduced pressure distillation, extraction, recrystallization, and distillation methods. However, the initial concentration of HCOOH affects the choice of separation and purification methods. In general, the concentration of HCOOH is in the range of tens of millimolar. For instance, at low concentrations, the selective permeability of semipermeable membranes can be used to separate formic acid from other components, such as using reverse osmosis or nanofiltration membranes. The high concentration of HCOOH vapor can be selectively produced in an all-solid electrolytic cell by using solid electrolyte. The resulting HCOOH vapor can be used directly to form direct formic acid fuel cells. Moreover, adopting solid-state electrolyte and MEA can avoid the separation and purification costs. At the same time, the concentration of CO2RR to HCOOH can be effectively increased, and the produced HCOOH can be directly used as fuel. Thus, constructing the entire electrolytic cell is extremely important for the application of industrial development. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic reaction can convert carbon dioxide (CO2) into formic acid (HCOOH), which is considered as a promising pathway for sustainable energy conversion and valuable chemicals production. Nevertheless, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) to HCOOH exists high reaction potential, insufficient active site and low product selectivity. In this review, various catalysts, including metal and metal oxides, metal-organic frameworks, covalent organic frameworks and carbon-based materials, are summarized from the structure-activity relationship between electrocatalysts and CO2RR performance. Then, the regulation strategies of morphology control, defect engineering, and interface engineering, to improve the selectivity and stability of CO2RR have been successively analyzed. In addition, the practical application of CO2RR to HCOOH in electrochemical energy technologies (formic acid fuel cells and water splitting) are comprehensively discussed. Finally, the perspectives and outlook of advanced catalysts for electrochemical selectivity reduction CO2 to HCOOH are thoroughly addressed. This review will be helpful to provide new insights for designing high selective and stable CO2RR to HCOOH electrocatalysts.
